section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: When we report what someone said, the verbs often shift into the past, because what the person said is in the past; will becomes would. Present tenses become Past tenses, Past Simple becomes Past Perfect.
section.text1a: He said he would finish it the next day.
section.text2: 'I'm working for a fashion company.'
section.text2a: He said he was working for a fashion company.
section.sectiontitle2: Time references and pronouns also change in reported speech.
section.text3a: She told me to call her later that day or the next day.
section.text4a: He said he would see us soon.

section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: We do not always need to change the tenses. If what the person said is still true, we can keep the present tense.
section.text1a: He said he still loves me.
section.text2: 'I'm living here until I find a job'
section.text2a: She said she is living here until she finds a job.
section.sectiontitle2:
Look at the verb patterns for say/tell. Say cannot be followed by a person.
Tell must be followed by a person.
section.text3a:
She said (that) it was late.
(NOT She said me it was late)
section.text4a:
He told me I was special.
(NOT He told that I was special)

section.title: Reported speech
section.sectiontitle: In 'Yes' or 'No' questions, ask is followed by if/whether.
section.text1: 'Do you know the way to the station?'
section.text1a: She asked me if I knew the way to the station.
section.text2a: She asked me whether I knew the way to the station.

section.title: Reported questions
section.sectiontitle: In reported questions the word order is the same as affirmative statements.
section.text1a: He asked me what I do.
section.text2a: She asked me which office they are in.
section.sectiontitle2: 'Yes' and 'No' questions use if/whether. Pronouns and time/place references may need to change.
section.text3a: He asked if I would still be there the next day.
section.text4: 'Did you enjoy going to Spain last week?'
section.text4a: She asked me whether I had enjoyed going to Spain the previous week.

section.title: Reported questions
section.sectiontitle: The tenses may shift back, as for reported statements.
section.text1a: She asked what time it was.
section.text2: 'Have you seen the film before?'
section.text2a: He asked if I had seen the film before.
